passages.text: Economics - Asia ex-Japan
Strong Q2 GDP is amplified by low deflators, one- off factors and is backward looking. The tariff impact will be visible after September.

- Real GDP growth rose sharply above expectations to \(7.8\%\) y-o-y in Q2 from \(7.4\%\) in Q1. In our view, this is not a signal of strong underlying demand, as it was boosted by low deflators, export frontloading, and its composition appears at odds with other high frequency data and demand signals.- Growth data appear mixed so far in Q3, but real GDP will get another boost from a low deflator, export frontloading (until August) and base effects, keeping it at an elevated \(7.4\%\) y-o-y. We expect the impact of higher tariffs to be visible after September, leading to a sharper slowdown to \(6.0\%\) in Q4 and \(5.6\%\) in Q1 2026.- Our view on the economic cycle remains unchanged, but given the higher Q2 GDP, we are statistically revising our FY26 GDP growth forecast to \(6.6\%\) (from \(6.0\%\) ). This implies average growth of \(5.8\%\) y-o-y in H2 FY26 versus \(7.6\%\) in H1 FY26.- The upside surprise in Q2 GDP, and with the RBI's FY26 GDP growth forecast of \(6.5\%\) looking realistic, markets have responded by questioning whether policy support is needed. In our view, high headline growth prints should not lead to policy complacency, given the drivers behind the rise, and the incoming growth shocks.- We believe a multi-pronged policy response is needed to support exporters and boost domestic demand: targeted fiscal/credit support, reform stimulus, diversifying India's export markets and monetary policy. We expect the RBI's MPC to be forward-looking, especially given the lags in policy transmission, and retain our forecast of 25bp cuts each in October and December, taking the terminal rate to \(5.00\%\) by end-2025.

GDP growth rose sharply to \(7.8\%\) y-o-y in Q2 from \(7.4\%\) in Q1, significantly above expectations (Consensus: \(6.7\%\) , Nomura: \(6.9\%\) ; Figure 1), with sequential growth moderating to \(1.7\%\) q-og, sa, in Q2, from \(2.5\%\) in Q1.

On the demand side, private consumption and exports were both stronger than expected. Real private consumption growth accelerated to \(7.0\%\) y-o-y in Q2 from \(6.0\%\) in Q1, above our estimate(4.0%), and with a stronger sequential momentum. With agricultural output lower (which is partially a proxy of rural demand), this would suggest that urban demand for goods and services consumption has been strong. Real export growth also picked up to \(6.3\%\) y-o-y in Q2 from \(3.9\%\) in Q1, which we believe reflects frontloading ahead of the anticipated reciprocal tariffs.

On the supply side, manufacturing and private services GVA growth were higher than expected. Manufacturing GVA growth rose to \(7.7\%\) y-o-y in Q2 from \(4.8\%\) in Q1, despite a moderation in manufacturing output growth, which suggests that a significant fall in input costs boosted profits and added to GVA growth. The strength in private services was led by the twin clusters of trade/hotels and finance/real estate services.
Three factors suggest that the strong headline real GDP growth is an exaggeration of its underlying trend.
- Role of deflators: A sharp fall in deflators is exaggerating real growth across sectors. Note that the statistical agency does not directly get data for real economic activity –

rather it is derived from nominal variables that are deflated using price levels for various sectors. The GDP deflator fell sharply to \(0.9\%\) y- o- y in Q2 from \(3.1\%\) in Q1, which led to a moderation in nominal GDP growth (to \(8.8\%\) vs \(10.8\%\) ), even as real GDP growth picked up (Figures 2 and 4). Higher growth in private consumption (where low food inflation plays a bigger role) was likely boosted due to this. Similarly, the pick- ups in export growth and import growth are not mirrored in the nominal trends. In fact, across many sectors, real growth accelerated even as nominal growth fell, reflecting the role of low deflators in boosting real growth.

- Discrepancy: The 'discrepancy' term contributed \(\sim 1.8pp\) to overall real GDP growth of \(7.8\%\) in Q2, compared to a drag of -2.1pp in Q1, so \(\sim 23\%\) of GDP growth remains unaccountable for now (Figure 3). This suggests the composition of GDP growth could get revised later.

- Inconsistency: For many components, a bottom-up estimate based on high frequency data did not match the actual GDP outturn. For instance, nominal central government capex rose \(52\%\) y-0- y in Q2 as did other investment proxies such as capital goods production, but real fixed investment growth moderated in Q2. Similarly, agriculture GVA growth moderated, even though strong winter crop production had indicated a pickup.

Overall, Q2 real GDP growth is significantly stronger than expected, but it is amplified by low deflators, driven by one- off factors (frontloading) and inconsistent with other demand signals (low inflation, slow credit growth, modest current account deficit), so we do not believe it is a sign of strong underlying demand. Importantly, it is backward looking.

Looking ahead, high frequency growth indicators in July suggest mixed performance (Figure 5). Rural consumption indicators (tractor and two- wheeler sales) are holding up, but urban consumption appears soft (passenger vehicle and diesel sales). Within the industrial sector, utilities are trailing, in part owing to monsoons, but infrastructure and construction output are holding up, likely due to public capex. Merchandise export growth should continue to be stronger into August, ahead of the implementation of the \(25\%\) penalty, but a slowdown is likely after September. Meanwhile, the coming GST rationalisation and expectations of lower prices will likely lead to lower consumer goods demand in August- September in the run- up to its implementation. Nevertheless, with the GDP deflator likely to moderate further in Q3, the disconnect between real GDP and high frequency data is likely to continue. Considering the higher starting point, we expect Q3 GDP growth of \(7.4\%\) y- o- y.

Our view on the economic cycle remains unchanged, but given the higher Q2 GDP, we are statistically revising FY26 GDP growth to \(6.6\%\) from \(6\%\) previously. Beyond September, we expect GDP growth to slow more sharply to \(6.0\%\) in Q4 and \(5.6\%\) in Q1 2026, implying average growth of \(5.8\%\) y- o- y in H2 FY26 versus \(7.6\%\) in H1 FY26.

The economy's headed into the crosswinds of the steep \(50\%\) US tariffs on Indian exports (see India: US tariffs hit \(50\%\) ; economic- policy inflection ahead, 27 August 2025) from end- August. Our base case assumes that the reciprocal tariffs will stay at \(25\%\) through FY26, but the \(25\%\) penalty will be removed after November. This threatens labour- intensive sectors such as textiles, gems and jewellery, household items and seafood, which now face an effective trade embargo. Second- round effects through job losses, factory shutdowns/relocation and a weaker investment climate may also follow. While GST implementation will lead to some surge in demand in October/November, the fundamental drivers of consumption - jobs and income prospects - suggest soft discretionary demand (see India: Macro effects of a GST rate cut; theory versus practice, 19 August 2025).

The upside surprise in Q2 GDP, and with the RBI's FY26 GDP growth forecast of \(6.5\%\) looking realistic, markets have responded by questioning whether any policy support is needed. In our view, high headline growth prints should not lead to policy complacency, given the drivers behind the rise, and the growth shocks ahead. We believe a multi- pronged policy response is needed (and likely) to support exporters and boost domestic demand.
- Targeted fiscal and credit support for exporters to cushion the hit to export orders and profit margins and tide over cash flow needs without displacing workers.

- Reform stimulus, including a finalization of the GST plabs Next week's GST council meeting on 3-4 September, alongside measures to improve ease of doing business, FDI liberalisation, deregulation, factor market reforms, privatisation, among others.
- Diversifying India's export markets through export promotion mission and fast tracking trade negotiations with other countries.

- Monetary: Even as headline GDP growth suggests economic resilience, the forward growth trajectory is pointing lower, and sustained disinflation below the RBI's 4% target provides the room to boost domestic demand (to offset the expected drag from exports). Hence, despite higher Q2 growth (backward looking data), we expect the RBI's MPC to be forward-looking, especially given the lags in policy transmission. We retain our forecast of 25bp cuts at each of the October and December meetings, taking the terminal rate to 5.00% by end-2025.

Source: CEIC and Nomura Global Economics
